title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Russia’s plan for ‘colossal’ science spending boost draws skepticism
items.description: Government pledges to more than triple research spending by 2030

items.title: A puzzling, 3.4-million-year-old fossil foot belonged to a contemporary of the famed Lucy
items.description: Identity of the toe bones and other fossils could shake up the human family tree

items.title: Who built a mysterious ancient city in western China?
items.description: DNA recovered from people buried at the site reveals surprises

items.title: Love practically makes these birds go blind
items.description: Unusually obstructive plumage compromises the vision of two types of pheasants—a first in birds

items.title: Vampire bats may have contracted H5N1 bird flu in Peru, raising worries about further spread
items.description: Bats could form a bridge between marine and terrestrial mammals, scientists say

items.title: Plan to alter Argentina’s glacier protection law draws criticism
items.description: Nation was first to legally protect frozen landscapes, a key source of water

items.title: NIH shake-up to grant decision-making draws concerns of political meddling
items.description: Policy drops “paylines” based on peer-review scores and requires geography and other factors to guide approvals

items.title: Popular obesity drug fails in hotly anticipated Alzheimer’s trials
items.description: The studies may still hold clues to the powers and limits of GLP-1 drugs

items.title: New vapor tool fights mosquitoes by slowly releasing insecticide in homes. Will it catch on?
items.description: World Health Organization supports “spatial repellents” to prevent malaria, but it’s unclear who will pay for them

items.title: Can a smaller U.S. National Academies remain relevant?
items.description: Loss of federal support leads to staff layoffs and fewer committees of outside experts
